displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: If it doesn’t work we’ll have to go back to the other OxyContin. Patient: Original. Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because that’s what you asked for. Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Well I thought maybe you was gonna give me another twenty and ninety. That’s what I was asking. Doctor: Well the Percocet we cannot give more than hundred twenty. Patient: Right. I know, I’m talking about OxyContin. Doctor: Yeah this is a long acting so it’s good for twe- twelve hours. So you only can take it morning and evening. Patient: Right. So I get twelve and twelve; I’ll take it at twelve and then I’ll take it again at twelve midnight.

Patient: The thing, yes. Doctor: However, what we need to do is get ahead of it. Patient: Right. Doctor: So we’ve got the Provenge in. I think there’s another set of pills, these are FDA approved. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: It is not experimental. Patient: Right. Doctor: And you know I’m always happy to consider stuff experimental- Patient: Right. Doctor: -but at this moment we don’t have one that is exactly like this. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Right. And this is ready to go FDA, four pills a day, Patient: Okay.

Patient: That’s a done deal. Doctor: So, again, only that thing is, you know, if it, we don’t start ‘til early January. Then, you get six cycles. So, then we’re talking March. The surgery may not be ‘til April or early May. Patient: Any of those other things they oughta, where, like the, the hormones - let them ride for a little while before chemo. Any other - Family Member: Good to knows? Patient: Good to knows. (Laughs) Doctor: Yeah. Uh, some of it’s style. Okay? So, my sense is, you know, there’s a number of us doctors who are appointed patients under the study, and the study allows a lot of wiggle room, uh, for how we approach it. Uh. It’s a little concern of mine that all of us could do a little bit differently. But, you know, there’s general consistency about how to do it. So, for me, it’s a style that, uh, giving hormones and chemo together, uh, you can really drop your counts out if you haven’t given it a little bit of space. So, one of the other doctors just gives a lower dose of the chemo, and, uh, like, like, okay, but I would rather make sure you get a full dose of chemo, a full dose of hormones, and if I just space it out a little bit, then we can probably keep that safe. Patient: Now, space it out a little bit, and I grabbed the number third of January, just outta the air. When you say “space it out a little bit,” from the beginning of the hormone treatment till, is it a week, ten days, a month? Doctor: Uh. Patient: Before you would start? Doctor: I mean, so we - in other studies, we’ve had up to about a four-month window that we could get the chemo started. In this study, it’s sorta that there is a definition, I think you said-- Healthcare Professional: It’s, umm. You’re talking about the protocols and parameters? Family Member: Yeah, the study itself. Doctor: Yeah. Thirty or sixty

Patient: Right. Family Member: Mhmm. Doctor: When you put those two together like a ratio, you’re a little dry so you need fluids. Patient: I, unfortunately, the last two days that’s been a little bit difficult because I was sitting in meetings. Doctor: Ahh. Okay. Patient: And driving so uh. Doctor: So you don’t really take fluids when you’re sitting in meetings… Patient: Well I don’t take as many… Doctor: …and driving. Patient: I don’t take as many fluids… Family Member: Not as much. Doctor: Okay.
